job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Romeoville, IL
pros: I have worked at IAG for many years. I love working with our individuals and think IAG supports it staff. We have gotten raises, gas cards, bonuses and during shut down (when we were still working) they gave out extra paper products, cleaning supplies and masks for staff for their homes since supplies were short. I love my job and the people I work with.
cons: None that I can think of

pros: fulfilling work that is dedicated to improving the life of others
cons: benefits work balance calls at any hour

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in East Moline, IL
pros: Meeting the individuals & caring for them.
cons: Pay is unfair Gossip is awful

pros: As an employee that began a career as a Direct Support Professional, I can say that IAG forged a path that allowed for personal growth and accomplishment. It is not only a job, but an opportunity to truly teach, advocate, and support individuals to live in an inclusive environment. The ability to empower others and witness their growth is the most rewarding experience and I so appreciate my superiors in giving the opportunity to do so.
cons: I honestly cannot think of any.

review_title: I currently assist administration with monthly finances for all person's served and CILAs within the region.
pros: Support from regional Director, administration and CEO.
cons: No cons for Individual Advocacy Group.

pros: It was a great starting point position. Able to build experience.
cons: Poor training. toxic environment. constantly changing conditions and expectations

pros: I have been with IAG for 20 years and have had many different opportunities. When I started, I worked in the field with many different individuals who needed assistance within their home environment. Since then, I have been able to move upwards in the company and have experienced many roles. The CEO is able to see the abilities of employees and supports the changes in roles to meet the agency needs. This agency provides a supportive atmosphere to all of the individuals served. I believe that all involved with this agency are working towards the same goal which is respect and support in all aspects of life.
cons: I do not have any concerns

review_title: Fun place to work and staff are respected
pros: I really like my job. I get to hang out with cool guys and help them live their best lives. It feels good to help them when they struggle. Staff work well with each other, and management seems to get rid of staff who like to bring the drama. The new director is cool and works with us in the homes. She is always available to talk to and listens to our concerns. Pay is pretty good and they give gas cards for thanks. Management is always on staff to make sure guys are looking good and place is clean.
cons: Work a lot but overtime check makes it worth it.

pros: If you want to work at an agency that takes the advocacy and care of the individuals we support seriously....then this is the place for you. Never have I worked with a more dedicated and caring group of staff. That is from the DSP's all the way up to the CEO. The CEO knows all of the individuals by name and they all feel like at any time, they can call, stop by her office or tell someone that they need to speak to her and it will happen. She takes their concerns and wants for their life seriously and acts on it accordingly.
cons: I have none at this time

review_title: Professional Growth  Possible and Great Team Work
pros: IAG strives to provide excellent care for the individuals that are served. Homes are very well maintained and individual choices and rights are respected. Quality work is the base line standard. There is dynamic team work, that makes the the quality care possible, in a fun supportive environment. Staff are regularly acknowledge through bonuses and appreciation gifts.
cons: Due to the fact that IAG supports peoples lives in 24 hour settings, challenges do arise. This can be stressful. However, our team makes a village of support for one another.

review_title: Good work good benefits good flexibility
job_title: Consultant/Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Fun place to work! :)
cons: A lot of walking. :)

pros: This company is very understanding to each person's life outside of work.  And genuinely care about its employees.
cons: I would love to work closer to home.  My con is my travel time and gas/ toll expense.

review_title: A place to work and make a real difference
pros: Promotion opportunities, cash bonus, flexibility, gas cards, training opportunities, longevity
cons: At times understaffed due to staff shortage

job_title: Case Manager (Individual Advocate) in Romeoville, IL
pros: You get to help people... Rewarding work.
cons: The work is very challenging and the pay is garbage. The owner of the company doesn't care about its employees whatsoever - she basically told us so. In a meeting, she said someone came to her with a complaint and her response? "There's the door."

pros:
Great community 
Rewarding
Flexible 
Understanding
cons: The company requires endless paperwork.

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Chicago, IL
pros: Rewarding work. If you are a good worker and team player, care about the individuals, ask for help, communicate with coworkers and your director, and are good about following protocol, you will do well. It is a steady job always in need of caring and hard-working people, and if you show the interest and ability, there is some room for growth when positions open up. The directors will work their best to support you when you face struggles. One of the owners of the company is a wonderful person who truly cares about providing services to individuals with disabilities. (I haven't met the other owner)
cons: Many people take this job because they think it is easy money, resulting in high turnover of unreliable and often lazy people. This can make your work more difficult at times. I also have yet to receive a raise I was promised, although I was paid the higher end of the wage range upon entering due to my experience and refusal to work for any less. Since homes are located throughout Illinois, meetings can sometimes be difficult to organize or take longer to organize.

pros: I'm not sure there are any.
cons: Difficult CEO/owner - always thinks she is right.

job_title: Direct Support Personal in Oswego, IL
pros: Early days and gets to go different places with the individuals
cons: Didn’t take covid seriously when first came around

review_title: Use to be a great place to work but they got away from their mission & purpose
pros: Working with the individuals was great, seeing their growth and being apart of them growing was great
cons: Low pay rate, lack of communication, lack of professionalism, lack of respect for African American staff, no true goals for the individuals, only care and make sure things in order when the state is coming out to audit.

pros: great people to work with
cons: no room for growth as its a non for profit organization

pros: Meet cool people ot comes and goes
cons: Management makes the job more stressful than it is

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Everything was great and smooth
cons: No come cons seen at IAG

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Moline, IL
pros: Working with the Individuals, & some of the coworkers
cons: Management, getting stuck on shift, & pay

pros: pay feels like family until they back stab you
cons: everything but the pay, cliques

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Romeoville, IL
pros:
Good training program,
Flexible schedule, 
Good leadership,
Always open to feedback.
cons:
Long hours,
PTO is not great.

review_title: no communication between corporate and house managers
pros: the office is full of kind and positive people. the support you are providing will mean a lot in the long run.
cons: corporate and house managers have little to no communication. i was told i would work some weekends and a set time frame each shift by corporate, but when i set my schedule with my house manager she told me schedules do not change and that i will be working every weekend. they should make the pay at least 15 per hour for the work that is asked to do..or there needs to be at least 2 DSPs per home - safety was a large part of the reason i did not feel comfortable remaining in this position. you train for a few days and then shadow for a full shift - i was not at all comfortable at my first day shadowing but i probably would have been more prepared if i would have done all of the training courses prior to shadowing. i was told by another DSP that you are told that there will always be at least 2 DSPs but that never happens - it is usually just one DSP.

pros: working time are flexible, good
cons: low salary , cannot reach the core work

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Moline, IL
pros: The pay was good and better than the competition
cons: Long hours, unexpected mandatory shifts, unorganized company, mean managers

pros: Absolutely none. Not a good place all - save yourself!
cons: The CEO Dr. Bennett is so very mean to her staff and even management equal to her. Stay away!

review_title: Not a TRUE Human Service Organization
pros:
Large organization that seems financially stable as a non profit. 
Regional offices throughout the state of Illinois and in DC, this shows growth.
Wonderful directors of regions in the state of Illinois.
Direct care staff that truly care for the individuals that they serve.
Willing to pay administrative staff well, with required education for the position.
cons:
Poor communication skills in the  corporate office.
No supervision of regional directors/administrators.
Executive Director does not seem very personable. No open door policy regardless of the verbal policy communicated by the corporate office.
The DIstrict of Columbia region of the agency are all related.
Unethical practices take place in the District of Columbia region and corporate office fails to investigate.
Unprofessional house managers. House managers do not exude professioinalism nor personable attitudes that should be exhibited in the human service field.
House managers are to work shifts along with us, but they often come in and walk out although their name is on the schedule.
The region as a whole will not grow as it should due to the poor man power of the administrative staff.
My current house manger is regarded as an administrative staff, but acts, talks and looks like a direct support worker with poor writing skills.

pros: The only good thing out of this horrible company is doing your best to make a difference in the client's lives and seeing them smile. Other than that, NOTHING.
cons: Countless cons. If you haven't noticed or read already, the CEO sucks! She told the staff to write good reviews online in order to cover up the truth. She makes money off the staff, and most importantly, the clients who are disabled/have special needs!! How disgusting! You can be on-call, work your butt off and yet, it will be looked down upon. A lot of shady business when it comes to the CEO and regional directors. Very unprofessional and horrible work environment, with horrible pay so don't be surprised if you don't receive a raise. As for a few of the staff members, they get paid to sit in clients houses and do absolutely nothing, but watch tv or play on their stupid cell phones. How disrespectful! They don't even make an effort to engage with the clients or assist them "live normal lives." Whatever that means. So much for making a difference in the clients' lives! I wouldn't advise working for this company or admitting clients to this company. Stay far, far away as possible! IAG claims to care for those in need, but in all reality, they only care about themselves.

pros: I used to work at another agency in the area that provides similar services. They weren't a bad company but they didn't offer the chance to grow that I have experienced at IAG. When you show that you are willing and able to take on more responsibility it is likely that you will get it.
cons: Like most work environments, there are some people that work here who do not take their jobs seriously. They are there for the money and complain every time management asks them to do anything. Fortunately, these people are few and far between. For those of us that truly care about the people we serve and show up everyday willing to work it is an awesome place to be!

review_title: Worst Social Service Agency of all time.
pros: Working with the individuals themselves was rewarding at times. Being able to see their growth, although usually very minimal, made it seem as if you were making a difference in their lives.
cons: Where to start? Understaffed, TERRIBLE upper management, lack of professionalism, no communication between house managers and employees, micro-managing led to many headaches, lack of consistency in treatment and care programs, terrible hours, terrible pay, lack of support, UNSAFE WORKING CONDITIONS!!! I worked there for about four months in one of the WORST homes in the agency. Changes in staff, individuals being moved and swapped from house to house, and medication changes led to EXTREME behaviors that were completely uncalled for and unsafe. I was attacked - bitten, hit, kicked, and scratched to the point of bruising and bleeding four times in a matter of two months. I couldn't take it anymore. This job drains you - physically and emotionally. It drives people to insanity. IAG is a TERRIBLE agency to work for. RUN, RUN, RUN!!! They claim that they care about their individuals, but if they cared about their employees at all the agency may operate better. Employee morale does not exist.

review_title: Wonderful Individuals, but understaffed and stressful
job_title: Direct Support Personnel in Romeoville, IL
pros:
The individuals are amazing people to work with, and love you simply because you are there.
Lots of great moments working with the individuals
cons:
understaffed!!! I was injured by a resident because I was the only staff there, when there was supposed to be at least two in the home.
No time off of any kind until you work there for at least a year. This includes family matters, or if you get sick. 
Many house managers don't seem to care about the residents, just want a paycheck.
They fire people for anything. Reporting that house staff are not doing their jobs will get you fired.

pros: The Individuals, and most of your Co-workers.
cons:
If you are a black woman that is a DSP most likely you will not get a raise. Upper management does not give two red cent about how long you've worked for the company. 

They will pay someone brand new way more then they will pay a loyal employee. You'll find out after 6months of being here that this company isn't for their employees. 

I've been here for years, and im still at the same pay as I started. I've seen people get paid way more money then me, and they didn't do a good job at all, plus majority of them didn't even last past a full year.

I am beginning to HATE upper management with a passion. If they all died tomorrow I would throw a party in celebration of their death. I can't wait to find another full time job

pros:
Company pays competitively compared to facilities offering similar services in the area. 
Working with the DD population is extremely rewarding. The individuals served were the only  motivation to go to work.
cons:
Leadership is extremely unprofessional. Two weeks notice does not exist. Despite having turned in two weeks notice with my resignation, I was subsequently laid off. The company lacks courtesy and professionalism in regards to staff. 
Staff morale seemed to be extremely low with many employees seeking employment elsewhere. A high turnover rate reflected this. 
Job duties and descriptions were unclear. Employees frequently being tasked with duties not included in their job description. 
Training is not conducted properly. There is no organization or structure with newly hired employees. This led to many mistakes being made and subsequent cover ups. 
With the high turnover rate, low employee satisfaction, poor training and rapid expansion (beyond reasonable means) the company is losing its foundation and is going to collapse inward on itself. All of this is being done at the expense of the individuals being served.

review_title: Dr. Charlene Bennett - great boss who gave me an opportunity
pros:
I have been fortunate enough to work for the Individual Advocacy Group (IAG) for over 12 years. Dr. Charlene Bennett gave me an opportunity to work for her Agency at a time when I really needed it and I have been happy since! I have learned a lot while working this job and have grown as a person in many ways. As the Fleet Manager and Maintenance Coordinator I learned so much about vehicles, appliances, heating and AC, etc.

Running the Day Training Center, I work with such great individuals. I get back from them more that I give to them. IAG takes care of so many individuals in need of help and support and helps them to have a positive, productive lifestyle. IAG is a great organization.
cons: I have not experienced any cons.

review_title: I enjoy going to work daily
job_title: Human Services Professional in Romeoville, IL
pros: I have been working at IAG for over 11 years and I have to say, I have never been prouder to work for an agency on a whole.  The devoted staff and the work that Dr. Bennett and Dr. Brooks have done to help so many individuals with special needs is inspiring.  From the beautiful homes that the individuals live in and the CEC day programs open across Illinois is astounding.  I enjoy going to work daily and because of the many positive stories I can tell my friends and family, they too are now happily working for IAG as well.  I hope to continue this journey with this agency and awesome staff until I retire!
cons: Throughout all of these years I have no issues or cons to mention.

pros: The staff are Individual Advocacy Group (IAG) are extremely professional and take an active interest in serving the clients - adults with mental illness and physical disabilities.
cons: The Chief Executive Officer - Dr. Charlene Bennett - is extremely abusive to staff.  She yells at staff in her office but it can be heard throughout the headquarters offices.  She exults in exercising her power - demanding staff jump to her every whim immediately (and I do mean immediately) even when involved in phone conversations or meetings not involving her.

pros: I love working with the individuals.  The individuals make my job so rewarding.  The staff I work with are great team players.  Management is supportive of our teams. The pay is great, higher than other agencies and the paid time off is great (4 weeks after 4 years).  My supervisor is supportive in my professional growth by assigning me additional things to do and gives me the training I need to do my job.
cons: No cons- individuals truly depend on you to be there for them.   Some parents can be challenging to work with.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Glendale Heights, IL
pros: I am the instructor of the Soothing Room at Glendale. I enjoy my individuals that I see everyday, we have a fun. We love soothing time while making interesting crafts and listening to soothing sounds. I would love to say that we have a great supervisor here. Steve is really good at his job also everyone who works here are good as well. I love to share my creative side with the individuals and I'm glad to be a part of IAG. This is a great place to work I enjoy and appreciate what us instructors can do to express our skills.
cons: I am very happy and satisfied working at IAG and I don't see any cons.

review_title: Micromanagement and hostile work environment created by female CEO
pros: Good pay for jobs like this is this area around here, middle management worked well with direct care staff, individuals were awesome to work with
cons: The woman who runs this company verbally abuses her employees by yelling and swearing at them, and blaming her actions on them, firing and demoting people without warning, everyone is afraid of her but scared to do anything because they need their job, and before I resigned the ceo said we had to go online to post positive reviews on these job sites because they were all so bad. Her co CEO does nothing but sees this every day

job_title: Human Services Professional in Oak Forest, IL
pros: I’ve been employed at IAG for eighteen years. When I came here I started as the lower level. IAG is a place that if you care and work hard, you can move up and be prideful. Since I’ve been here it’s always been fair, my head CEO has given me a chance to grow in lots of ways. Also Dr. Bennett, she’s thoughtful to your needs, as well as making easier for you to stay employed. But I love my job, the individuals and my work associates. It’s a family.
cons: To date, I can't think of any issues that I have experienced.

review_title: It has been a great pleasure working here
job_title: Direct Support Instructor in Romeoville, IL
pros: I have been working with IAG for 14 years and during that time it has been a great pleasure working here. The work that I do here has been very beneficial to me as well as the individuals that I serve. We strive to provide quality care for our individuals and that makes me feel good to come to work daily. I take great pleasure in showing up to do my job daily. It makes me feel that we are doing a great service for the people that we serve.
cons: I have experienced no cons at this time.

pros: Not many, it’s a JOB!
cons: Increased turnover, individual to staff ratio low, nurse is inattentive to individuals problems, you have to beg for a raise, managers are not concerned about staff concern,  company has declined tremendously! Insurance is ridiculously high, don’t offer sick time, vacation time, or personal time individually like almost any big company just PTO 120 that increase after two years but still not worth it! Staff can be really rude and obnoxious.

pros: I get to work with people with disabilities that need lots of help.  Some times I work in their house and sometimes I work at their day program.
cons: I don't always get to work with the pep,e that I. Used to and I miss them. It can be hard to get to know a new person inside and out. I think thats true for any agency though.

pros: I liked my coworkers (most of the time) and I got a lot of experience working with special needs people.
cons: Not everyone I worked with was positive about their jobs. Guess they picked the wrong career path. I'm going to school for special recreation and this was a good place to start but also hard because of the long hours.

pros: I was able to have fun everyday making people with disabilities smile. If you hate your job you should find one that makes you happy.
cons: It takes a few months to get PTO but I think that is true for a lot of companies. After you are there for a couple of years you get a month off.

job_title: Director of Nursing in East Moline, IL
pros: I appreciate the level of professionalism here. Everyone at the office works as team and is like a family. When supplies or equipment is needed, there is no hesitation. I feel appreciated. Because of the teamwork and everyone pitching in, the people we support are well cared for in terms of their health/medically. IAG caters to what the people we support really want, not just what we think they want.
cons: I have not come across any cons of working here so far.

pros: Helping individuals with various disabilities, support from fellow staff and knowing you can make a difference in someone else's life.
cons: CEO is hostile and no matter how hard you work she belittles you, curses at you and gives employees an obscene amount of unnecessary work...and does  this in front of fellow employees. CEO needs to remember this agency is about the individuals...not her or looking good on paper.

pros: I have worked in the provider community in DC for almost 20 years. IAG is the only place I want to be. The level of integrity and support here is bar none. IAG promotes independence, well-being and safety for people supported, as well as developing and promoting staff to maximize their potential. The expectation is for excellence every day. I love coming to work every day.
cons: At the present time I can't think of any cons.

pros: Working with this population is awesome! The staff were great and hard workers. The pay was higher than any other social service agency in IL.
cons: CEO micro manages everything, uses unprofessional language, and berates/bullies everyone, CEO expects everyone to be available and work 24/7, high burn out rate, high turnover rate (even with high pay rates), high high stress environment created by CEO and counter part, every week you feel as if you are going to be fired

job_title: Direct Support Personnel in Chicago, IL
pros: Your allowed to do many things with the clients and are able to take them places where they can have fun.
cons: Sometimes i feel communication could be better coming from superiors. also a lot of employees don't get the recognition for the hard work they have to do daily

pros: Staff from top to bottom are dedicated to clients served. Opportunities for overtime exist. Great to see a company care for an often forgotten population.
cons: Often short staffed, lots of staff turnover therefore others work long hours. Company operates in crisis mode and takes on work before prepared.

review_title: Very unsafe and an owner who is cruel to employees.
job_title: Direct Service Provider/Day Program Instructor in Geneva, IL
pros: Very few if any. The line staff can be very supportive.
cons: You will not have the support you need to stay safe. Expect to be hurt on the job. Also, expect the owner of the company not to have a clue what the work actually is. She will NEVER pay you a livingwage if she can avoid it. She will not support you with regards to injuries that happen at work or even when your life is threatened by a client. The direct staff is amazing but turnover is incredible.

pros: The work with individuals was wonderful. I did not have contact with administration. The work was rewarding but hard sometimes.
cons: I got called a lot outside my schedule to fill in for other people a lot which is why I had to leave but I got good experience and was hired somewhere else pretty fast.

pros: The individuals, some of the coworkers
cons: The female CEO, 401k, health benefits, pay

pros: IAG does the best they can with the pathetic funding provided by the state of IL to service individuals with intellectual disabilities and pay their employees higher rates than other agencies in the area.
cons: I do not live close to the region where I work so I have a long commute.

pros: Working with the individuals. Watching them thrive and learn when staff has the time to  give them the attention that they need. Also, working with several great coworkers.
cons: Dangerous working conditions. There are never enough staff to safely deal with the often violent behaviors. The pay is way too low and the lack of communication with those in charge, cause very good employees to leave. High turn-over rate.

review_title: My experience was very memorable and made me more conscious.
job_title: Office Manager in Oak Forest, IL
pros: I was able to be hands on with the clients and employee, which allowed me to build a repor with them.
cons: There wasn’t a lot of listening to the clients needs. There was more delegating than positive giving back to the community.

pros: Most staff care about the individuals
cons:
Senior Management micromanages, fires people without cause, HUGE into drama and gossip. 
They sell a great ideal but the day-to-day is much different. 
Management are bullies.
If you value your career - stay far away from this organization.
There is no trust and you are not allowed to do the job you were hired for.

pros: AG is like a big family. I really care about the people we support. They are interesting people with great personalities. I like the management and the environment in general.
cons: None that I can think of.

pros: Loved the individuals and my direct supervisor.  Enjoyed coming to work daily and interacting with my co-works and the clients.
cons: I liked it...I don't have anything negative to say

review_title: Great clients & Co-Workers bad payroll workers
pros: Benefits, Pay, clients, co-workers, flexible hours
cons: Payroll always messes up on checks & PTO Always!!

pros: Everyone is supportive. There is a lot of support from every department. We are able to grow.
cons: Have yet to experience any.

pros: Rewarding job that makes you feel like you make a difference.
cons: overnight hours. stressful at times.

job_title: Direct Service Professional in Romeoville, IL
pros:
Hours-if you get a day shift
Ability to help people with special needs
cons:
Lack of management
Horrible pay and benifits
Fired half of my training class within the first week
They will fire you for the smallest thing
5 pto days/year this includes vacation and sick time

pros: Cool clients and ok staff. Nothing else was that spectacular.
cons: That CEO is a really awful person. No one likes her. Everyone talks about her behind her back. She really needs to take a chill pill and go back to school To relearn how to treat people with respect.

review_title: good place to work and grow
pros: a place with a lot to learn
cons: nothing that I have noticed

pros: great people to work with
cons: nothing to complain about here

pros: Help others with daily lifestyle needs.
cons: Physically challenging, and hands on work.

pros: Helping Others Less Fortunate then your self
cons: Rate of Pay For  Work Done .

pros: Watching the smiles of  clients that may be lucky enough to benefit from time with those of us that care.
cons: Unsafe and unsanitary working conditions. Horrible communication, lies and extremely low pay.

pros: Working with individuals who are awesome.
cons: CEO….HORRIBLE! Does not know the first thing about working with people.

pros: High Pay, Coworkers, Residents, Work from Home option
cons: CEO, Poorly Organized, Chaotic, Bad work/life balance
